OVERALL
This is a pretty neat, satisfying incremental/idle game that is JUICY as hell. I played the demo, loved the ideas, and immediately got the full game on release. For a £7.50 / $9 it's a great deal. It's definitely worth a go if you like idlers/incrementals, and/or love the overall feel of this from the main vid. There are a few rough edges, and this isn't a crazy long grind style idle game, it's a relatively short, single player idler with some light management to keep it interesting, great characters, cool artwork and effects, and a BANGING soundtrack. 

PROS
- Good balance between passive idling and active interaction - chill, not overwhelming
- Soundtrack slaps, HARD.
- Artwork is fantastic, game juice/FX excellent - very satisfying experience
- Progression system is well constructed and feels interesting at its heart
- Doesnt descend into 'number on screen go brrr', the visuals and worldbuilding (however simple) make it work

CONS
- Scaling is a bit rough round the edges, with the early/mid game unlocks coming in thick and fast, then slowing down very quickly toward the end, which forces some grind, which feels a little off for this game. You get a bit too much too quickly, but it's still good stuff.
- Signposting for the prestiging system (soft vs hard prestiging) is a little unclear - the soft prestiging feels like cheating, honestly.
- Partly because of the scaling thing meaning you unlock almost everything really quickly, it feels like the game needs a couple of extra 'things', there's a decent amount going on, but because you end up spending a lot of time with all the current systems/buildings etc, it feels like there needs to be more of a mid-late game mechanic that's introduced

In conclusion, I rate this, and I'd recommend it if you like idlers/incrementals, as it feels pretty fresh. I personally hope that the dev keeps working on refining the game, and hopefully adds more content/DLC in the future!

After 100%ing everything, I can say most of my playtime was pretty boring. After clearing the game once by taking down the 13 bosses (which really only takes one prestige), the rest of your game time is going to be taken up by grinding. You need at least 600-700 kills on each boss to guarantee max rarity, and more to get the materials to max them out. 

This is 90% of the content in the game. Builds range from "one-two shotting the final bosses" to "potentially taking half an hour per kill", meaning that not optimizing just feels like a giant waste of time. At the top end, there's really only two viable builds. There used to be more, but they snapped the game in half too much and were nerfed. So the main selling point of theorycrafting builds is pointless because there's no incentives for anything other than speed kills.

The power spikes that you get in incremental games that give you dopamine are very rare, with them coming only from item rarity upgrades and progressing in the skill tree. Progressing in the skill tree is odd, as the most effective way of doing so is to stockpile a bunch of resources and then getting the funds as quick as possible to purchase the buildings that let you buy more skill points. This means that  it both incentivizes speed kills and also doesn't really let you toy around with builds.

I didn't even bother doing that, so it took me 76 hours to get everything done. However, I was paying attention for only 5 of those hours tops.

It was a fun game for a little bit, but it becomes a waste of time eventually. Poorly balanced items, prestige can actually hinder you pretty severely, and most units are just worthless to use. My high amount of hours was just me grinding bosses until I had a ton of their loot for a personal set goal, and because I really didn't have another incremental to play at the time.

It's a $10, 20 hour idle game.  Pass on something this expensive that doesn't even offer the basic "reset for big big number" that defines the genera.  Sure there's a reset but its not even necessary to complete the game.

Cool concept/shell but didn't feel well executed to me. Hopefully updates make this into something great.

One second you have everything maxed out with the money you're currently earning- all the damage you can possibly do, a great build with MAXED out related items boosting your build, and then the next you're doing like, no damage on a level one boss. [h1]A Promising Game That Turns into a Grind Fest[/h1]
[b]OBS! THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS[/b]
[b]TLDR at the bottom[/b]

After 74 hours of playtime, I have finished all achievements, unlocked every possible pet and almost maxed out the Talent Tree. And before I leave this game to the depths of my steam library, I thought it fitting to leave a review explaining my experience with the game.

[h2]Quick Summary of Game Resources[/h2]
The game is about slaying one selected boss monster repeatedly to obtain resources such as [b]Materials[/b], [b]Items[/b] and [b]Gold[/b]. 
[b]Gold[/b] lets you upgrade buildings and recruit followers which help you slay the boss. 
[b]Items[/b] give special effects by being equipped to Advisors.
[b]Materials[/b] are used to upgrade the strength of Items.
All of this is shown clearly in the Gameplay Trailer.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
With the Game Resources explained above, covering the gameplay loop becomes a lot easier because it's not very complicated.

[u] The beginning of the game[/u]
The game starts off slow with the player slowly amassing upgrades and increasing their damage. Depending on what the player chooses to focus on, the time it takes to transition into mid game can vary by a lot. Personally, it took me a combined three hours of active gameplay to find a way to skyrocket my progress. It was the [spoiler]Farmlands building.[/spoiler]

By combining [spoiler]the Farmlands building[/spoiler] and [spoiler]the item [b]Ruff[/b][/spoiler]. I was able get into the gameplay loop the player will be running up until they finish the game.

[u]Mid game to late game[/u]
Mid game starts once the player has unlocked most upgrades and buildings. At this point, the Player has also unlocked the [b]Prestige[/b] system. This, as shown in the Gameplay Trailer images, is a tree full of upgrades for the various buildings and followers.

Up until this far, the Player has probably been sticking to one build or trying out multiple by combining Advisors, Items, Followers and Buildings. Looking at the Prestige Tree, they wonder "What other builds can I make to become stronger".

To unlock more nodes on the Talent Tree, the player unlocks two buildings, the [b]Alchemist[/b] and the [b]Marketplace[/b] and start farming bosses to obtain more resources which they trade in for Divine Gems every 20 minutes.

This is the most broken down and straight-forward progression path that I can describe as well as the one I myself took.

[h2]My thoughts and critic[/h2]
I had fun at the start. The first five hours or so was quite active and it felt like I had an impact on the game with my builds. However, as time went on, a very big issue became glaringly clear as I unlocked more and more nodes and Items. [b][u]There is next to no build variety.[/u][/b]

I'm a very build oriented person so I made a few builds. Sadly, most of them eventually didn't have the damage scaling for later bosses or were painfully slow, making them feel obsolete. Very few builds actually  ended up working and a lot of the nodes on the Talent Tree do basically nothing. Some Items sound strong but when put into action, they fall flat.

Outside of builds, the grind of items also became very boring. After entering the mid to endgame stage, I spent most of the time just having the game open while I played League or WoW. This is because there was nothing else for me to do in the game. I farmed Items and resources.

[b]What could be better?[/b] [i]imo[/i]
[list]
    [*]More bosses
    [*]More Items
    [*]More pets
    [*]Give some pets unique abilities
    [*]Give certain followers more strength through additional nodes or items
    [*]Improve the Collection Progress system - It stops around midgame
    [*]Rework the way you get Divine Gems, the current system is just a boring grind
    [*]More complex Wheater mechanics
    [*]Rework the Resident system - It's currently very one-sided and becomes a very limiting factor
    [*]Add rewards for completing certain achievements
    [*]Add ways for the player to add color the game. 50+ hours of grey is boring.
[/list]
These are just a few of the things I came up with but I'm sure if I played through the game again, I'd find other things to point out. 


[h2]TL:DR / Final thoughts[/h2]
To summarize whether the game is worth it's price tag - I'd have to say no. While the game's core is promising and if expanded upon can evolve into something very impressive, as it stands right now, it only captivates you just enough to keep the game running in the background while you do chores or play another game.

The game has potential, but there's a single serious flaw. Stagnation.
If you play for several hours, you slowly grow bigger and better. But at some point everything just runs to a halt and things stagnate. I had a solid 2 hours of fun, the remaining 16 hours felt like pain...

Eventually, you'll unlock the "prestige" system, which is nothing more than a fancy reset button. It does not bring you any increased benefits if you were to prestige multiple times like you would in other idle games. Instead, the game wants you to read up on all the skills, perks, equipment, to then try to find a "build" that should break the game. But from what I hear, the developer seems to nerf builds occasionally so it gets hard and harder to progess.

And eventually, the ONLY consistant way of progressing, is by waiting 20 minutes, and then buy a prestige point from the shop... And with 2 shops, that's 6 points per hour at most. And that's assuming you have the materials to buy them, which you likely won't. And you don't need just 6 points... you'll want to get 200+.

Everything in this game is designed to slow you down, nothing makes you feel strong. if something makes you feel strong, it'll get nerfed. You'd think they'd just move the goalpost further, no. instead they shoot your kneecaps to prevent you from progressing.

If you like excessive reading, and constant min/maxing while attempting builds that each may take HOURS to figure out if they work or not, then sure, this could be a cool game. But for the vast majority of people... this aint it.

The game starts off strong, with plenty of new buildings and customization options that make it enjoyable to play. However, after a few hours, it devolves into a grindheavy experience where progression practically comes to a halt.

At that point, it becomes more of a background activity, just sitting there as the bosses gets taken care of by the slow poison build-up, with little interaction required from the player.

It breaks my heart to not recommend this game because I can tell a lot of passion went into it, but I cannot in good faith recommend it. 

I like 100%ing the incremental games I play, they're usually fun 1-8 hour experiences and have some neat gameplay or interesting decisions made by indie and solo developers. This game nails it, plus awesome art and music, until you get out of the early game. Like by the 5th or 6th boss, it's incredibly slow. I would've loved this game if it took me 6 hours to beat, not 60, most of that time of which was AFK just letting the kills rack up.

It is possible I had a bad build but I really don't think I did. I experimented with a lot, I soft and hard prestiged a bunch, I even reviewed guides to see if I was missing something. There are two core problems with the pace of this game:

1. EIther boss health or player damage scales WAY too high in the late game, even some of the most optimal builds I could afford (more on that later) just took forever, especially when most bosses need to be defeated 1000 times.
2. Actual progression in this game relies on Divine Gems, which aren't a paid currency thank nuts, but are extremely timegated. You need to wait 20 minutes to be able to purchase 2, and in the mid game especially its very likely you won't have what you need to trade, or you would be trading something far more valuable such equipment for a rarity upgrade.

The most recent update seems neat, but it doesn't really fix the core problems in my opinion.

No disrespect to the devs, this is a really neat and cute game, I enjoyed it especially in the beginning when I was present enough to enjoy all the different artwork and music; but with love, there are flaws.

Game quickly turns from fun and interesting into a slow progression, where most of what can be done is limited. Shops reroll every 20 minutes and half the time the offers are just horrible. It was fun in the beginning, but the progression shat its self 6 hours in of mostly idle gameplay. The only thing to do after 4 hours was wait, not wait and do stuff, wait and do nothing. It was a disgrace to run it on my pc at that point.

The game is initially fun. It becomes a bit too grindy for me about half way through the game. That is another issue as well, unfortunately 'half way through' is about one day. Beat the game on the second day. That was it. After you kill the last boss there is literally nothing left to do except let the game grind and grind and grind into oblivion. Fun concept, however there is no 'meat' to this skeleton.

It's quite repetitive and disappointing. The idea is you keep killing the same bosses over and over and you optimize your build by farming materials that they drop. The bosses do nothing, they are just PNGs with a health bar. Unfortunately the actual theorycrafting space is super cramped and the items take forever to farm (yes, I know it's an idle game), and once you bring them to max level, you realize that the build they enable won't even scale fast enough, forcing you to essentially start over. 

The synergies you end up with are nothing to write home about. The usual "developer was creatively bankrupt so they added fire/ice/poison elemental damage that forces you into mutually exclusive upgrade paths". That's pretty much all the complexity there is and it doesn't even TRY to be different about it. Bosses with resistances and you with elemental weapons. Everything else is "number go up" gameplay and RSI simulator, with none of the charm of the original Cookie Clicker.

So while it could probably redeem itself, I believe that this is a $2-3 game at most, definitely not a $10 game.

Initially really fun!
But the balance is off and the rebirth/respec tree is annoying, unbalanced and uninspired.

I will say, it was a nice game, but the grind is not very tasteful.

It feels like a lot of the upgrades are useless. The light spears to me, feel useless unless you get items and skill points in them. At no point I felt compelled to even try the items because when I unlocked it, it was just bad, useless and doing no damage.

The game had a nice early game, but the late game doesn't feel that well thought of. Once you reach your first prestige, you can say you finished the game as there won't be that much more to do except bigger numbers, but there's no content after that, you will have gotten all of your upgrades and all gameplay changing things in a few hours and after... mindless grind that doesn't feel rewarding at all.

I would not recommend unless there is more content

The fun falls off hard after 5-7 hours. Everything after that point is a massive, un-fun grind for minimal upgrades. This damage ceiling leads to unbearably slow bossfights as early as 3-5 bosses before the end meaning the only way to beat them is to leave the game running for long periods of time, all for small meaningless upgrades.

Like many others, bait and switched by the demo. Demo felt great, actual release was just like "look at what they did to my boy" simulator. Nerf. Nerf. Nerfs all around for everything, everything nerfed. Everything slower. Drop rates nerfed, but you need MORE items. Game has a hard barrier at around 5/6 hours into it, making it realistically impossible to progress without putting the game on the side for a full day.

It quickly becomes boring in the mid-late game. The incoming power creep doesn't feel gradual, it feels like going from 25->30->40->1000. One second you have everything maxed out with the money you're currently earning- all the damage you can possibly do, a great build with MAXED out related items boosting your build, and then the next you're doing like, no damage on a level one boss. And upgrades don't feel like they're following that progression or closing that gap, nor does the upgrades in the skill tree. I was shocked when I maxed out how much money my farm could make, and I still had four bosses I hadn't gotten to beating and farming yet. 

The addition of up to 4 levels of a boss doesn't feel like it helps that at all? It's cool for farming items when you can kill the 4th level boss quickly, but it doesn't solve the sudden and drastic jump to really strong bosses and no monetary gains to follow it.

Overall, I'd give this a mixed if Steam had that option. The art is really cool, the boss designs are awesome, and the early game is fun. It just stops being fun during the period you'd be spending the most time with it, the mid to late grind, so I can't recommend it.
Starts well then grinds to a halt with a very odd prestige system.

The game has potential, but there's a single serious flaw. Stagnation.
If you play for several hours, you slowly grow bigger and better. But at some point everything just runs to a halt and things stagnate. I had a solid 2 hours of fun, the remaining 16 hours felt like pain...

Eventually, you'll unlock the "prestige" system, which is nothing more than a fancy reset button. It does not bring you any increased benefits if you were to prestige multiple times like you would in other idle games. Instead, the game wants you to read up on all the skills, perks, equipment, to then try to find a "build" that should break the game. But from what I hear, the developer seems to nerf builds occasionally so it gets hard and harder to progess.

And eventually, the ONLY consistant way of progressing, is by waiting 20 minutes, and then buy a prestige point from the shop... And with 2 shops, that's 6 points per hour at most. And that's assuming you have the materials to buy them, which you likely won't. And you don't need just 6 points... you'll want to get 200+.

Everything in this game is designed to slow you down, nothing makes you feel strong. if something makes you feel strong, it'll get nerfed. You'd think they'd just move the goalpost further, no. instead they shoot your kneecaps to prevent you from progressing.

If you like excessive reading, and constant min/maxing while attempting builds that each may take HOURS to figure out if they work or not, then sure, this could be a cool game. But for the vast majority of people... this aint it.

This game feels like an idler game which is trying not to be one.

Major upgrades cost citizens, and once you upgraded it, you can never get them back, this would be fine, except that your citizens have a cap, and it's impossible to upgrade everything, you can only really focus on two different races(warrior,troll,bird etc.) since even their damage upgrade cost 20 citizens.

And the 'hard reset/rebirth' function is atrocious, your weapon and phoenix experience also gets reset back to 0, especially the phoenix, since to level it up you have to manually click on it, resetting it's progress again.

I can guess why the developer made it this way, to make this game more 'strategic', which comes to my first point, this is an idler game, why does it need to be strategic? What is wrong with being really brainless and overpowered?

Idler games are supposed to be satisfying, yet the game design seem so unsatisfying. 

And the recent update made this game even more unsatisfying to 'play' with item nerfs, I feel like the developer is trying to make this game have longer playtime by dragging the fight longer, but that just made me feel less likely to play.

The unsatisfying factor outweighs the satisfying factor of an idle game in my opinion.

Remove the citizen cost for upgrading.
Don't reset phoenix's level when hard reseting.
Keep the original pre-nerf clock's ability, but make it so you can only get to this at max level.
Change the eye boss's ability.

After 100%ing everything, I can say most of my playtime was pretty boring. After clearing the game once by taking down the 13 bosses (which really only takes one prestige), the rest of your game time is going to be taken up by grinding. You need at least 600-700 kills on each boss to guarantee max rarity, and more to get the materials to max them out. 

This is 90% of the content in the game. Builds range from "one-two shotting the final bosses" to "potentially taking half an hour per kill", meaning that not optimizing just feels like a giant waste of time. At the top end, there's really only two viable builds. There used to be more, but they snapped the game in half too much and were nerfed. So the main selling point of theorycrafting builds is pointless because there's no incentives for anything other than speed kills.

The power spikes that you get in incremental games that give you dopamine are very rare, with them coming only from item rarity upgrades and progressing in the skill tree. Progressing in the skill tree is odd, as the most effective way of doing so is to stockpile a bunch of resources and then getting the funds as quick as possible to purchase the buildings that let you buy more skill points. This means that  it both incentivizes speed kills and also doesn't really let you toy around with builds.

I didn't even bother doing that, so it took me 76 hours to get everything done. However, I was paying attention for only 5 of those hours tops.

Quite a sad situation we have here. Coming from the demo, everything looked nice. Progression and bosses felt well balanced, artwork and UI are good. Sadly the full game does not really build on this foundation. Progression continues a bit further quite well, but then you're stuck. Unit upgrades takes way longer, while the impact doesn't scale. Only way to progress later on (killing bosses, but also quickly killing bosses for farm) is to level up items and skill tree (called hard and soft prestige). For the items you need to farm the bosses and that for quite some time. The later bosses have annoying mechanics (without any good counter) which stops you from efficient farming and you require 1111 of each item to fully upgrade, with a ~20% drop chance. The skill tree requires tokens, which you get from achievements and can buy from items you farmed. The more you have, the better your build can become. With soft prestige you can only extend your current skill tree. If you want to fully reset the tree, you can do a hard prestige and reset your whole progress except items and prestige points. While you can easily come back to around 4/5 of the progress, the last part takes forever as scaling is so weird. Then again it does barely matter, as 99,9% of the damage is coming through elemental damage from the items, thus many upgrades for units are completely useless, especially damage, as it does not scale.

I played similar games for much longer, but somehow they did not get boring, as progression always brought great new stuff. This isn't the case here and such I cannot recommend the game. At the point you finally have enough points and item levels to create a cool build, you have already solved everything there is in the game. If they would increase the progress a bit in the current "end" game so it doesn't get that boring and instead develop something challenging to tackle if you got all the items and skills, I could recommend this game. In the current state you've seen the best of it after you've played the demo.

In-depth Analysis/Review (mostly for devs)
Prestige System
How should I put this, the system is really underwhelming, over roughly 100 hours of game play, I only Hard prestiged twice, and because the skill tree is so limited in comparison, the existence it has in the game is almost something you can do without.

Imbalance/Lack of tuning with respect to Equipment Synergy And Skill Tree Builds.
I believe that the game would be more fun if all the units/items and their respective synergies all worked just as effectively before taking into consideration boss resistances/skills. My opinion is like this because the skill tree is really simple, the progression is linear and the only flexibility you really have in the game is the type of builds you have, while early game it does not matter much, personally I find that as you move towards the end of the game, there is only one or maybe two skill builds that are efficient hence resulting in cookie cutter builds.

Lack of content
I think recently the standard on Indie games have risen immensely and I believe that this game is really not worth it. Although I have played for roughly 100 hours, technically speaking realistic gameplay is only maybe 4-5 hours with most of it in the early game and me just AFK waiting for resources to roll in, to press the upgrade button once.
